[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The neck is composed of soft tissue with underlying bones and muscles. It is compliant, deformable, and sensitive to applied pressure. Estimated mass affected by the grasp is about 3 kg (portion of head and neck supported). The skin and muscle provide moderate friction when grasped, estimated static friction coefficient around 0.6.
- Environmental Factors: The man is seated, supported by a table beneath. Gravity acts downward on the neck and head. The robot must maintain a gentle but firm grasp to avoid slipping or injury. Human tissue damping and compliance dissipate small force fluctuations.
- The relevant object is the man’s neck and part of the head, composed of soft tissue with some underlying bone structure, with an effective mass of about 3 kg and a static friction coefficient of approximately 0.6 between skin and robot gripper material.
- The surface of interaction is human skin and clothing, which are soft and slightly rough, with a static friction coefficient of about 0.5 relative to the robot gripper pads.
- Contact Types: The robot will maintain a palm-encompassing pinch grasp around the neck. Contact is compliant and requires moderate normal force to maintain the grasp without causing discomfort or injury.
- Motion Type: The robot will perform a combination of gentle grasping, sliding (up and down along the neck), light tapping, circular rotation, and mild lifting within the comfort range to relieve tension and promote massage.
- Contact Considerations: Additional force components on lateral axes are required to maintain grasp stability during dynamic motions. Normal force along the grasp axis must be maintained higher than shear forces to prevent slip.
- Motion along axes: The robot will perform a combination of linear and rotational motions across wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes: gentle sliding along +Z (upward along neck), small linear lateral adjustments along X and Y, rotation about Y-axis (side-to-side neck massage), and mild rotation about Z-axis (circular massage motion). Small angular adjustments about X-axis will fine tune wrist orientation.
- Task duration: A thorough neck massage should last approximately 60 seconds, with continuous, smooth motions and variable force modulation for comfort and efficacy.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: 
  Mass affected ~ 3 kg, gravity force ~ 29.4 N (3 kg * 9.8 m/s^2)
  Static friction coefficient ~ 0.6 (gripper-skin)
- Relevant equations:
  Required normal grasp force F_grasp to prevent slip: F_grasp > F_shear / μ_static
- Relevant assumptions:
  Tissue compliance absorbs some forces safely; maximal grasp force does not exceed 20 N to prevent discomfort.
- Computations:
  To counteract shear from motion and maintain grasp without slip:
  Assume shear force peaks at 5 N during sliding movements,
  F_grasp > 5 / 0.6 ≈ 8.3 N minimum,
  use grasp force range 10 to 15 N for safety and comfort.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 3 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface:
  Sliding force along +Z up to 5 N,
  mild rotational torques about Y and Z axes up to ~0.5 N-m,
  fine tuning torques about X axis ~0.2 N-m.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the lateral fine adjustment motions and to maintain lateral stability, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 2 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the grasp stability and minor lateral tuning, the robot must exert negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude 2 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis:  To complete the task and based upon the upward sliding motion to massage the neck, the robot must exert positive linear force along the Z-axis with magnitude 4 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the mild wrist orientation adjustments, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.2 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the rotational side-to-side neck massage motions, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon the circular massage wrist rotation, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force:  Estimated force range to avoid slip yet provide comfort is 10 to 15 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python

property_description = "Human neck tissue with underlying bone, approx. 3 kg mass, compliant soft tissue with static friction coefficient ~0.6 to robot gripper, skin and clothing surface friction ~0.5"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Sliding upward along Z-axis, lateral tuning along X and Y axes, rotational side-to-side about Y, circular rotation about Z, minor orientation adjustments about X"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [2.0, -2.0, 4.0, -0.2, 0.5, -0.5]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 12.5
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 60.0
```

[end of motion plan]

Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
